newsitem.title: USA: U.S. debt fund managers remain bullish -- MCM.
newsitem.headline: U.S. debt fund managers remain bullish -- MCM.

text.p: U.S. fixed-income managers maintained a bullish exposure in their debt portfolios over the past week, according to an MCM MoneyWatch Inc survey.

"This group is bullish ... and not intending to bail until inflation surfaces or the economy shows more signs of life," said MCM money market analyst Peter McTeague, who conducts the asset allocation survey.
The weekly survey showed durations as a percentage of benchmark rose to 106.3 percent in the week ended October 21 from 105.8 percent in the prior week.
A duration reading above 100 percent indicates the group of investors polled is mostly long on the market.
A portfolio's duration represents its average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.
In the "next likely move" category, portfolio managers representing 12 percent of total assets in the survey said they would "buy," down from 14 percent the prior week.
Strategists leaning toward "sell" also fell, to 26 percent, down from 34 percent in the week ended October 15.
Sixty-two percent of managers said they were "neutral" on the market, up from 52 percent a week ago.
Cash as a percentage of assets fell to 2.49 percent, against 2.68 percent registered the previous week.

The survey showed 20 percent of investors polled overweighted the 10-plus years duration sector, down from 21 percent in the previous week, while 28 percent underweighted it. The remaining 52 percent were "neutral."
In the five- to 10-year duration sector, 49 percent of investors polled said they overweighted the securities and 16 percent underweighted them.
The survey included 40 domestic participants, who manage about $100 billion in fixed-income assets. The poll is conducted weekly by MCM and usually is released on Tuesday.
